Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Geoarchaeology of Estuarine Seascapes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: The focus of this doctoral dissertation research project is to reconstruct the roles that coastal Native American societies played in the establishment and transformation of nearshore estuarine ecosystems. Previous geoscientific and archaeological work has studied the evolution of estuaries as non-anthropogenic or ‘pre-anthropogenic’ ecotones, and conceptualized Indigenous maritime societies as passive inhabitants of bountiful and dynamic environments. This dissertation research will integrate geoarchaeological and paleoecological approaches to reconceptualize coastal peoples as ecosystem engineers and tidal estuarine habitats as the products of deep-time human-environmental interaction. This dissertation research will produce historical reconstructions for the process of marine transgression along the Gulf Coastal strand, knowledge of estuary management by Native Americans, and pre-industrial baseline data for measuring modern sea-level rise and historical degradation. <br/><br/>The project will investigate the general hypothesis that ancient Indigenous societies engineered nearshore ecosystems through the construction and maintenance of terraformed shellworks. The research will be conducted at several well-preserved archaeological complexes along a large open-water estuary system that was intensively occupied by Native American populations. Sedimentological, paleobotanical, and radiocarbon analyses on sediment cores and archaeological excavation units will be correlated to reconstruct the geological and ecological relationships between Indigenous shell-terraforming and the establishment of protected, low-energy intertidal habitats. Feedbacks between anthropogenic habitat modification, subsistence production, and the emplacement of civic architecture will be assessed by comparing the core records with zooarchaeological assemblages and construction sequences of midden-mounds. This interdisciplinary dataset will contribute to improved ecological and anthropological understanding of intertidal ecosystems. The study will be carried out in consultation with local and regional land managers and conservation agencies with the explicit intent that results and research products may be integrated into management, conservation, and restoration planning.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This dissertation research has substantially refined archaeological and geoscientific understanding of Tampa Bay and its history of estuarine development over the Holocene. New, well-dated geological and paleoenvironmental records enable us to reconstruct sequences of ecosystem change throughout the inshore areas of the estuary, from the late-Pleistocene to the present?addressing a major spatial and temporal knowledge gap in the geoscientific literature. A major theme of the geologic history developed here is the interaction of marine and climatic forcing with antecedent karst bathymetry and minimal sediment supply - producing an enigmatic pattern of estuarine development that contrasts strikingly with more straight-forward flooding histories of most Atlantic coast estuaries. Outside of the Florida Gulf Coast, these records will be of prime utility for researchers working in tropical and sub-tropical estuaries formed on limestone substrates. Our archaeological work was focused on six previously under-studied Native shellwork sites that lacked radiocarbon chronologies and controlled sub-surface sampling. NSF funds enabled a robust radiocarbon dating program, and these six sites are now among the best-dated shellwork complexes on the Florida Gulf Coast. Rigorous mollusk-zooarchaeological and sedimentological analyses at shellwork sites enable us to reconstruct complex site-formation processes (e.g., midden-deposition, mound-building, storm-taphonomy) and related shifts in harvesting strategies. Perhaps most importantly, our investigations at shellwork sites were seamlessly integrated with the estuarine paleoenvironmental work, enabling us to situate ancestral Native settlement and terraforming within the geologic framework of the estuary. This approach explicitly counters the persistent omission of Native societies from paleoenvironmental histories in Florida and shows that Indigenous peoples significantly modified the morphodynamics of inshore estuarine sub-basins and influenced the manifestations of late-Holocene marine transgression.

Broader Impacts:

This research has produced important geologic, paleoenvironmental, and cultural histories that contextualize the emerging realities of modern climate change and sea-level rise on the Florida Gulf Coast. We track major shifts in the rate of marine transgression across the mid- to late-Holocene and show that coastal ecosystem transfer in Tampa Bay during the common era has been affected by a minor punctuated excursion of sea-level ca. 1.8 kya, and by increased tidal and wave forcing during hurricanes. We propose that many Indigenous shellworks sites (and their encompassing seascapes) represent models for future coastal 'green infrastructure' projects - particularly projects seeking to deploy ecologically-suitable coastal structures to buffer erosion, expand tidal wetlands, and hold-off the process of 'coastal squeeze'. We recommend that future geoscientific studies in Tampa Bay's inshore zones empirically measure bathymetry, tidal flow, and wave-forcing to model the how ancient indigenous shellworks currently affect modern tidal circulation, wave behavior, and storm surge.
